report_title: Pump & Compressor Manufacturing in the US
executive_summary: Most products in the Pump and Compressor Manufacturing industry are used by companies in the mining, manufacturing and utility sectors. As a result, demand for pumps and compressors is often determined by a variety of economic factors. For example, oil production volumes and energy prices have a direct effect on industry revenue and profit. In addition, the industry is characterized by its extensive participation in foreign markets. In 2024, exports are estimated to represent over one-third of industry revenue, while imports satisfy almost one-half of domestic demand. Canada and Mexico are major trade partners due to their geographic proximity to the United States. China also accounts for a substantial portion of international trade, largely because of low wage costs.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Exports are on the downturn while imports continue to flood in
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Over the five years to 2024, industry revenue is expected to decline at a CAGR of 4.0% to $28.1 billion, including a projected increase of 0.8% in 2024. The decline is largely explained by the outbreak of COVID-19, which had a negative effect on the entire economy, with industry revenue declining 17.5% in 2020 alone. In the latter part of the current period, industry revenue has partly rebounded from the negative effects of the pandemic as the US economy experienced growth overall, but industry revenue is estimated to remain below pre-pandemic levels in 2024. Moreover, imports' share of industry revenue has also climbed due to a rising value of the US dollar and other macroeconomic factors.

Despite its importance, exports have continued to dwindle, as it has crept downward over the period. This has stemmed from strong foreign competition and an appreciating US dollar. The pandemic slashed exports as international trade was constricted because of health and safety regulations. Import penetration continues to plague domestic companies since foreign manufacturers typically have lower labor costs and can price their products more competitively.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Pump and compressor manufacturers have continued to invest in technology and consolidate
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: The increasing popularity of smart pumping systems, which use computer technology to reduce energy consumption and lower life cycle costs, has allowed manufacturers to differentiate their products. Many large manufacturers are investing more in environmentally friendly technologies, partly driven by government incentives. To get access to new technologies and expand geographically, pump and compressor manufacturers have steadily consolidated over the past five years. The most notable consolidation occurred in 2020 when Gardner Denver Holdings Inc. merged with Ingersoll Rand Industrial, bolstering the new company's presence in the industry and making it one of the largest players. M&A activity has constrained industry participation, with the number of pump and compressor manufacturers expected to fall.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: DOWNSTREAM MARKETS RECOVER – PUSHING THE NEED FOR PUMPS AND COMPRESSORS
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Construction markets are set to recover, driven partly by a growing economy and increasing consumer confidence. Residential construction is set to face some early hiccups as the Federal Reserve continues to combat inflation. Private nonresidential construction will thrive as projects held off during the pandemic will resume. Utilities construction is also set to expand as a growing population increases investment in aging US infrastructure. The newly passed Infrastructure Investment and Jobs Act will provide federal funding to help update existing infrastructure like roads and bridges while also enabling all Americans access to utilities like clean drinking water and high-speed internet.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: INDUSTRY IMPORTS ARE SET TO FALL DUE TO A WEAKENING US DOLLAR
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: The presence of low-cost imports will continue to pose a threat to domestic manufacturers. Companies will face price competition and continue to make adjustments to help deter consumers away from lower-cost goods. Many end markets still prefer US-made goods because of their quality and durability. A depreciation in the US dollar will make imported goods more expensive, resulting in declining imports into the domestic market. Even so, over two-fifths of domestic demand is still set to be fulfilled by foreign pumps and compressors. Exports are set to recover as a weaker US dollar makes domestic pumps and compressors more affordable globally.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: INNOVATION AND RESHORING MAKES ITS MARK
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Specialized products and greater product infiltration across major downstream markets will aid revenue growth. These projects require systems that meet new standards for efficiency, which increases costs per item. Large projects will provide a consistent flow of revenue through replacements and upgrades. Some companies will focus on niche or sustainable products to align with ongoing trends. Investments in research and development will help create components that will help reduce energy usage. Oil-free air compressors will also see heightened popularity because of their ability to reduce waste and contamination. Rising labor costs in lower-wage countries will reduce the competitive advantages of offshoring, limiting declines in industry enterprises.

industry_definition: Operators in this industry manufacture pumps and compressors for general use, measuring and dispensing. In addition, the industry manufactures nonagricultural spraying and dusting equipment and provides aftermarket and repair services for customers. However, pump and compressor manufacturers do not manufacture fluid power pumps, pumps for motor vehicles or air-conditioning compressors.
key_trends: Competition from foreign companies is high since the cost of production abroad is often lower.
Competition is the most extreme in the aftermarket services market; overall, competition is moderate due to a large variety of products.
Import penetration has continued to grow, resulting in higher price competition domestically and affecting profit growth over the past five years.
COVID-19 has contributed to heightened volatility over the past five years due to volatile construction markets.
Market share concentration has been low and consistent over the past decade, with no companies accounting for more than one-tenth of revenue.
Exports represent a significant source of revenue for major players, while imports represent the major threat.
Clean water and clean air laws are the main regulations faced by pump and compressor manufacturers, similar to many other manufacturing industries.
Industry assistance is low; reduced trade tariffs represent the main source of assistance.
Purchase costs are more volatile than other costs, affecting the most by commodity prices and other economic factors.
Rising import penetration has been the major challenge when it comes to sustaining profit for pump and compressor manufacturers domestically.

market_segmentation.segment_description: This segment includes food and beverage, pulp and paper, pharmaceutical and plastic manufacturing industries. Pumps and compressor companies act as original equipment manufacturers for other machine manufacturers. Most popular pumps and compressors demanded by manufacturers include centrifugal pumps, vertical turbine pumps, reciprocating pumps, rotary.

This segment includes mining, oil and gas industries. These industries are mostly concentrated in the Southwest region of the United States. Pumps and compressors are needed to pump massive quantities of water and chemicals out of mines. Oil well pumps are also critical for oil extraction and compressors are key when operating in gas-related industries.

This segment includes utilities and construction industries. The geographic distribution of these industries aligns with the geographic distribution of the US population. The construction of water infrastructure and sewage systems relies extensively on pumps and pumping equipment. In addition, residential homes often add sump pumps to their water system infrastructure to prevent basement drainage.

Other markets include but are not limited to service and transportation industries. The geographic location of these industries aligns with major US population hubs. Demand for industry goods from other markets depends on the performance of each individual industry within this segment. However, on a macro level, demand is driven by overall economic growth.

This segment includes industry products manufactured for exports. Major export destinations include Canada, China and Mexico. Demand for US exports depends on such factors as the price competitiveness of industry products globally, the value of the US currency and US trade relationships with major recipients of US exports.

products_and_services.product_description: This segment includes centrifugal, reciprocating and nonagricultural spraying and dusting compressors. Air compressors convert fuel into energy in the form of compressed air.

This segment includes heavy-duty process pumps that are typically used to move water, wastewater, oil or chemicals. Industrial pumps vary by application and include piston pumps, diaphragm pumps and screw pumps, among other models.

Other pumps and equipment include oil well and oil field pumps, domestic sump pumps, parts and attachments for air and gas compressors, industrial spraying equipment, vacuum pumps, parts and attachments for measuring and dispensing pumps and contract manufacturing services.

demand_determinants.determinant_description: Exports, which are partially determined by changes in currency exchange rates, generate a substantial share of industry revenue. An increasing trade-weighted index (TWI) reflects an appreciating US dollar, which raises the cost of US goods, encouraging import penetration and depressing the value of industry exports. A falling TWI represents an opportunity for the industry.
Manufacturing capacity utilization affects demand from manufacturing industries. A decrease in capacity utilization usually leads to lower demand for pumps and compressors.
Demand from energy-related industries like mining, oil and gas is influenced by oil and gas production levels. Increasing domestic extraction has supported demand from this segment.

The level of construction activity influences demand for air and gas compressors from utilities and construction industries. Over the past five years, declining construction activity has reduced demand.
Demand from other markets like service and transportation industries is driven largely by overall economic growth.

international_trade_points.trade_description: Over the five years to 2024, the value of imports has increased, driven particularly by rapid increases in imports from China.
A strengthening US dollar and well-established production processes in Germany contribute to rising imports from Germany over the past five years.

Total industry exports have declined over the past five years due to rising competition from foreign manufacturers with lower labor costs and the strengthening US dollar making US goods more expensive abroad.
Canada, Mexico and China are major export destinations, along with emerging markets in Brazil, Chile and Colombia. Asia's manufacturing sector provides a large export market.

business_locations.location_description: The Southwest is the largest oil and gas production hub in the country, so demand for pumps and compressors is high. Texas alone is home to many industry establishments in 2023 since it's also a major oil and gas production region. Oklahoma also demands pumps and compressors since it's known for its mineral resources such as natural gas, metals and industrial minerals.

The Southeast region's share of the US population is higher than the region's share of pump and compressor manufacturers nationwide. However, the region still has a high number of establishments due to the region's large population, which affects demand from downstream markets. The largest states within the region are represented by Florida, Louisiana and Georgia.

The Great Lakes region's share of pump and compressor manufacturers is higher than the region's share of the US population, which shows that the region has competitive advantages over other regions. Ohio dominates the region due to the high importance of the manufacturing sector in the state, being a key market for manufacturers. Wisconsin is the second-largest state in the region and is known for its strong involvement in the manufacturing and agricultural sectors. This makes it an attractive market for pump and compressor manufacturers.

Excluding energy-related industries, which are highly concentrated in certain states such as Texas, the number of manufacturing and construction companies in a given state largely determines demand for pump and compressor products. The number of construction companies in each state is mainly determined by population. California, which belongs to the West region, is the largest state by the number of pump and compressor manufacturers.

regulations_points.regulation_description: The Clean Air Act (CAA) aims to limit the emission of harmful air pollutants along with volatile organic compounds (VOCs). Air-pollution control regulations affecting the industry are detailed in Titles 1 and 40 of the CAA's Code of Federal Regulations (Parts 50-99). Title 1 is concerned with National Emission Standards for Hazardous Air Pollutants. Regulations designed to limit VOCs have been in existence since the 1970s.

The Clean Water Act (CWA) restricts the level of discharge made by pump and compressor manufacturers, forcing some that have excessive discharge to seek more expensive, alternative forms of waste disposal. Manufacturers discharging into the United States' waters require a permit under the National.

The industry is subject to the Clean Water Act and the National Pollutant Discharge Elimination System program. Alternatively, if an operator discharges process wastewater to a city sewer system, it must meet pretreatment standards.

The industry is challenged by potential regulations related to noise pollution. For example, in Pennsylvania, regulations currently state that compressor stations located on forest land cannot be louder than 55.0 decibels from 300.0 feet away; however, guidelines may vary by state. Despite growing attention to noise pollution caused by compressor stations, there has been no material legislation on the matter. Pump and compressor manufacturers also encountered some regulations amid COVID-19 in 2020, though such regulations have had a minimal effect on the industry.

barriers_points.barrier_description: The industry is in a mature life cycle stage.
The industry assistance level is low and steady.
The globalization level is high but decreasing.

basis_points.basis_description: Competition from foreign companies is high since the cost of production abroad is often lower.

concentration_points.concentration_description: A wide range of products reduces competition by creating niche markets.
Strong competition from abroad limits market share concentration domestically.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Volatile Commodity Markets Affect Purchase Costs
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Similar to many manufacturing industries, this industry incurs high purchase costs due to the high role of input materials. In addition to input materials, this segment also includes capital expenditures for machinery and buildings. Purchase costs have remained relatively steady over the past five years and comprise the largest industry expense.

Wage costs as a share of revenue have climbed over the past five years. The increase has been driven by employment not falling as much as revenue. In addition, the average wage also declined. Despite the underlying manufacturing process, labor in this industry is required to provide technical support, conduct quality assurance, develop and distribute products, among other activities.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Economic Growth and Rising Imports Affect Profit
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Profit, measured as earnings before interest and taxes, has declined over the past five years.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: The industry depends heavily on equipment and input materials as purchase costs account for nearly half of industry revenue. Capital costs vary from year to year based on fluctuations in commodity markets.

volatility_points.volatility_title: Economic and Production Cycles Affect Revenue Trends
volatility_points.volatility_description: Volatility for pump and compressor manufacturers is driven partly by economic and production cycles. When the economy expands, industrial and construction activities typically rise, contributing to higher demand for industry products. However, industrial and construction activities have declined over the past five years.

volatility_points.volatility_title: Unexpected Disruptions May Cause Revenue Swings
volatility_points.volatility_description: Events such as the outbreak of COVID-19 or major geopolitical events can shift industry cycles via supply chain disruptions or reduced demand.

technological_change_points.technological_change_title: HIGHER THROUGHPUT AT A LOWER COST
technological_change_points.technological_change_description: Clients prefer pumps and compressors that use less power and produce higher output.

FAQs.question: How do imported pumps and compressors affect demand for your products?
FAQs.answer: The level of import penetration in the industry is high. China is the largest source of industry imports, followed by Mexico and Germany.

FAQs.question: How much does your company depend on exports?
FAQs.answer: Exports account for a significant portion of industry revenue. Canada is the largest destination of US-manufactured industry goods, followed by Mexico and China.

FAQs.question: What are the main factors affecting demand for your products?
FAQs.answer: Demand for industry products depends on equipment upgrade cycles and procurement cycles. Such cycles can be extended during poor economic performance. One way industry operators can drive demand by introducing more energy-efficient and safer products.

FAQs.question: How much competitive pressure do you experience from larger industry operators?
FAQs.answer: The industry has a low level of concentration. Therefore, the level of competition from larger operators is high only in certain geographies.

FAQs.question: Have you been able to reduce wage costs and continue operations safely through automation over the past year?
FAQs.answer: Operators have been able to contain wage costs through automation in this industry.

FAQs.question: What steps do you take to safeguard your company's proprietary information?
FAQs.answer: Industry companies regularly file patents for new products or processes that they develop.

FAQs.question: How does international demand affect revenue?
FAQs.answer: As this industry significantly depends on exports, demand from international countries is vital to operations.

FAQs.question: Have any regulatory changes significantly affected your operations recently?
FAQs.answer: Production facilities Companies in this industry are subject to oversight from the Environmental Protection Agency.

FAQs.question: How much money does your company spend on wages?
FAQs.answer: The average annual wage at the four largest companies is higher compared with the rest of the industry.

FAQs.question: How does your company's profit compare with your main competitors'?
FAQs.answer: Profit is suppressed by high competition from abroad.

FAQs.question: Is your technical expertise to a world standard? How much does your company invest in innovative technology to enhance day-to-day operations?
FAQs.answer: Access to internationally competitive technology through in-house research and development or licensing agreements benefits operators by stimulating replacement demand.

FAQs.question: How do you maintain product quality? Do you have systems in place to keep standards high and continually updating?
FAQs.answer: Quality control systems help achieve uniformity across product lines and encourage brand loyalty.

FAQs.question: Which niche markets, if any, do you cater to?
FAQs.answer: Operators can benefit from specialization in an appropriate market niche like oil and gas or utilities.

FAQs.question: Does your company depend on oil and gas companies? World production of oil
FAQs.answer: The energy sector uses pumps and compressors for the extraction and transport of oil and natural gas. High crude oil production volumes result in more demand for pumps and compressors.

FAQs.question: Has your revenue trended in line with the industrial production index?
FAQs.answer: Pumps and compressors are used in a variety of sectors, including mining and manufacturing; the industrial production index (IPI) measures the output of these sectors. High levels of industrial production generally lead to increased freight levels; therefore, when the industrial production index is high, industry manufacturers typically benefit.

FAQs.question: How much of your revenue is derived from utilities construction? Did demand from this segment help your performance?
FAQs.answer: The industry generates a portion of revenue from the construction of utilities, as pumps and compressors are used to control the flow of liquids through water and sewage systems, which are found in all major towns and cities across the United States.
